sec.title: Objective
sec.p: (1) To compare the rate of surgical site infections in ear surgery between groups with and without hair removal and (2) to study factors associated with surgical site infections.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: A preliminary, randomized, controlled trial.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: University hospital.

sec.title: Subjects and Methods
sec.p: The study was conducted in a group of 136 patients who underwent surgery for external or middle ear disease via the post-auricular approach at Chiang Mai University Hospital from May 2010 to May 2011. Demographic data, surgical site infection within 30 days postoperatively, and associated factors were recorded.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Fifty-eight cases were men and 78 cases women. Demographic data between the 2 groups were compared. Age, gender, the side of operated ear, types of anesthesia, emergency or elective setting, body mass index, history of alcohol and/or tobacco use, underlying diseases, operative time, and the length of hospital stay revealed no significant differences. A postoperative surgical site infection developed in 5 patients: 3 in the group with hair removal (4.5%) and 2 in the group without hair removal (2.8%) (P value = 0.674, Fisher’s exact test). All infected cases had undergone mastoidectomy.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Surgical site infection rates between the 2 groups (with and without hair removal) demonstrated no difference. Hair removal prior to ear surgery via post-auricular incision had no effect on the rate of surgical site infection.

body.p: Surgical site infections (SSIs) are the most common nosocomial infections, which can lead to revision surgery, delayed wound healing, increased antibiotic usage, longer hospital stays, and higher health care costs.1,2 Ear and mastoid is listed in site-specific classifications of organ/space surgical site infection.3 Hair removal is one of the preoperative issues listed in guidelines for the prevention of surgical site infection.4

Three common incisions have been used for the middle ear and external ear surgery. These include the post-auricular incision of Wilde, the endaural incision of Lempert, and the transcanal incision. The post-auricular incision provides the best exposure in surgery for chronic otitis media, cholesteatoma, temporal bone fracture with facial nerve paralysis, and external ear canal stenosis. In adults, the post-auricular incision is placed 8 to10 mm posterior to the post-auricular sulcus where it is hidden by the pinna.5

The routine removal of body hair from the intended surgical wound site has been traditionally performed preoperatively.6 Many surgeons claim that preoperative hair removal reduces the chance of postoperative SSIs and facilitates planning, attachment of the drapes, and closure.7 The currently used methods of hair removal are: shaving, clipping, and chemical depilation, with shaving being the most common and cheapest method.

Shaving of the hair can cause microscopic lacerations to the skin and result in a breakdown of the surface barrier. This type of injury may lead to the colonization and invasion of the skin bacterial flora, impair wound healing, and eventually increase the risk of local infections.4,8-11A systematic review of preoperative hair removal to reduce surgical site infection has been published, but there is no evidence that this holds true for ear and mastoid surgery.6

The psychological effect of hair removal appears to be quite significant and lasts for several months, since the hair takes considerable time to grow back. Self-esteem often reaches an all-time low, interfering with rehabilitation and social integration.11

The aims of this study are: (1) to compare the rates of surgical site infection between two groups (one with preop hair removal, the other without) and (2) to study factors associated with surgical site infections. Both groups consisted of patients who underwent ear and/or mastoid surgery via post-auricular incision.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This study was conducted at the tertiary care Chiang Mai University (CMU) Hospital. The study protocol was approved by the CMU Ethics Committee. Each patient recruited to this study received research information and signed informed consent prior to enrollment. Patients who were scheduled for ear and/or mastoid surgery via post-auricular approach between May 2010 and May 2011 were recruited. Patients younger than 18 or older than 60 years and those with evidence of infection in the operative area prior to surgery were excluded.

One hundred forty-nine cases were scheduled for ear and/or mastoid surgery during this preliminary study period. Eight cases outside the age range of 18 to 60 were excluded from the study. Thus, 141 cases were randomized into 2 groups, with and without hair removal, by block randomization using random allocation software (Figure 1).

In defining SSIs, we referred to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) National Nosocomial Infections Surveillance (NNIS) system.4 Post-auricular incision infection is classified as a deep incisional SSI. The criteria included are: (1) infection occurring within 30 days after the operation if no implant is left in place, and the infection appears to be related to the operation; (2) infection involving deep soft tissues (eg, fascial and muscle layers) of the incision; and (3) at least one of the following: (a) purulent drainage from the deep incision but not from the organ/space component of the surgical site; (b) a deep incision spontaneously dehisces or is deliberately opened by a surgeon when the patient has at least one of the following signs or symptoms: fever (>38ºC), localized pain, or tenderness, unless site is culture-negative; (c) an abscess or other evidence of infection involving the deep incision is found on direct examination, during reoperation, or by histopathologic or radiologic examination; (d) diagnosis of a deep incisional SSI by a surgeon or attending physician.

Preoperative patient care and skin preparation were performed in the same fashion in both groups. Each patient shampooed his or her hair with an antiseptic solution the night before the operation. In the hair removal group, the area of the post auricular was shaved with a dry razor. In all cases before the operation commenced, the entire operative field was scrubbed with chlorhexidine scrub followed by painting with 10% povidone-iodine solution.8 Excess solution was removed with sterile gauze, and the operative field was then allowed to dry. The surgical field was isolated with sterile towels. The area of intended incision was marked and infiltrated with a local anesthetic agent. The indicated procedure was then performed. All wounds were closed in similar manner, simple interrupted vicryl periosteal closure and running vicryl the subcutaneous closure to approximate the skin edges. Drains were not used. Mastoid packing was applied.
Demographic data, surgical site infection within 30 days following operation, and any associated factors were recorded.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Because 5 cases were lost to follow-up, 136 cases (58 males and 78 females) were included in the database analyzed. The hair removal group consisted of 66 cases, the nonshaven 70 cases (Figure 1). In the hair removal group, duration between shaving and the start of operation ranged from 0.9 to 27.1 hours (16.7 ± 6.7; mean ± standard deviation [SD]).

Demographic data of both groups are shown in Table 1. Operative procedures performed in the two groups are shown in Table 2. Numbers of cases categorized by wound classification4 are shown in Table 3.

sec.p: Surgical site infections developed in 5 cases (3.7%), 3 cases in the hair removal group (3 of 66 = 4.5%), and 2 cases in the non–hair removal group (2 of 70 = 2.8%). The rate of SSIs showed no statistical difference between the two groups (P-value = 0.674, Fisher’s exact test).

The wound infection rates were 1.1% (1 of 89) in clean wounds, 8.1% (3 of 37) in clean-contaminated wounds, and 10.0% (1 of 10) in infected or dirty wounds. Details of the 5 cases with SSI are shown in Table 4.

sec.p: Case 1 had hypertension, dyslipidemia, and asthma. Case 4 had hypertension. Bacterial culture was performed in both: case 1 reported Staphylococcus aureus, and case 5 reported Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus.
All SSIs were treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and local wound care in an outpatient setting. All healed completely and without further complications.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The rate of SSI in ear and mastoid in this study, 3.6%, falls within the range found in previous studies. The overall rate of SSIs has been reported as 1.2% of 589 surgeries,12 2.3% of 5109 procedures,13 3.34% of 6167 surgeries,14 4.75% of 23,649 surgical wounds,15 and 8.6% of 857 minor surgery cases.16 Staphylococcus aureus was the most frequently isolated microorganism.13

All SSI cases within our study underwent mastoidectomy. Therefore mastoidectomy should be considered as an SSI risk. The length of time between preoperative shaving and commencement of surgery was 21.8, 17.7, and 22.7 hours. The longer the duration between hair removal and the start of surgery, the higher the rate of SSI expected. Shaving the night prior to operation, especially more than 24 hours preoperatively, tends to increase the SSI rate. This is especially true if more than 24 hours elapse.17 Other associated risks for SSIs mentioned in previous reports are: diabetes, obesity, contaminated and/or dirty wounds,16 skin preparation, sterile technique, and surgical duration.1 None of these were obvious in this study.

The rate of SSIs in this study demonstrated no differences from previous reports, as shown in Table 5. Sample size was calculated by an estimation of the difference between the rates of surgical site infection.18

caption.p: Rates of Surgical Site Infections (SSI) in Groups with and without Hair Removal

sec.p: The rate of SSIs in the non–hair removal group (2.8%) was 37.8% lower than the rate in the hair removal group (4.5%). Although the rate of SSIs between the 2 groups showed no statistical difference, the 37.8% difference should be considered of clinical significance.

According to Figure 2, with a sample size of 66 cases in the hair removal group and the nonshaven at 70 cases, it is possible to detect the difference in infection rates if the ratio between the rates of surgical site infection is about 70 at 60% power.

caption.p: Illustration of how the difference between the rates of surgical site infection of the 2 groups affects the required sample size.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The rates of infection between the shaved and nonshaved patient groups demonstrated no statistical difference. Avoiding hair removal in ear surgery via the post-auricular approach would appear to be preferable. Hair removal can and does cause psychological discomfort, sometimes delaying rehabilitation and a return to normal social activities. Further study and/or meta-analysis to measure this assumption objectively is encouraged.
